name: Citrus greening (HLB)
summary: Citrus greening, also known as Huanglongbing (HLB), is a devastating disease affecting citrus plants. It is caused by a bacterium transmitted by insect vectors, primarily the Asian citrus psyllid. The disease results in mottled leaves, stunted growth, and deformed fruits, ultimately leading to the death of the tree.

cause_of_disease.describe: This is the bacterium most commonly associated with citrus greening and is transmitted by the Asian citrus psyllid.
An insect vector that spreads the bacteria from infected plants to healthy ones.
Using or moving infected nursery stock or plant materials can spread the disease to new areas.

steps: Implement regular monitoring for psyllid populations.
Use insecticides or biological control agents to manage infestations.
Remove and destroy infected trees to prevent the spread of disease.
Research and select citrus varieties known for resistance to HLB.
Replace susceptible trees with these more tolerant varieties.

tips: Regularly inspect trees for signs of HLB, such as yellowing leaves or misshapen fruit.
Prevent the spread of the disease by controlling psyllid populations in and around citrus groves.
Work with local agricultural extension offices to stay informed about HLB management practices and updates.
